Content: Use the information in Source 1a to help you answer this question.
Which question can 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 be answered by performing Hot Pack Investigation 1?

A.Choice: How will the temperature of the water in each jar affect the hot pack?

B.Choice: How will the temperature of the water in each jar change during the 10 minutes the box is sealed?

C.Choice: How much thermal energy will be transferred between the instant hot pack and the water in each jar?

D.Choice: How much thermal energy will be transferred to the surrounding air during the 10 minutes the box is sealed?

Content: Use the information in Source 1b to help you answer this question.
Which 𝗧𝗪𝗢 statements support the student's claim that the matter and energy of the instant hot pack are conserved even though the temperature of the instant hot pack changed?

A.Choice: The mass of the instant hot pack did not change because the amount of matter was constant.

B.Choice: The mass of the instant hot pack did not change because the total amount of energy was conserved.

C.Choice: Matter was conserved because it flowed from the hot pack to the arm, as shown by the temperature data.

D.Choice: Energy was conserved because it flowed from the instant hot pack into the arm, causing the arm to warm, as shown by the temperature data.

E.Choice: The instant hot pack transferred energy as cold flowed from the arm into the hot pack and changed the temperature of the arm, until both were at the same temperature.

Content: Use the information in Source 1c to help you answer this question.
Which claim is 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 supported by the student's data?

A.Choice: A salt solution with more mass will have a higher temperature than a salt solution with less mass.

B.Choice: A salt solution with more water than salt will have a higher temperature than a salt solution with more salt than water.

C.Choice: A salt solution with a higher ratio of salt to water will have a higher temperature than a salt solution with a lower ratio of salt to water.

D.Choice: A salt solution with a greater total volume of salt and water will have a higher temperature than a salt solution with a smaller total volume of salt and water.

Content: Based on the data, which 𝗧𝗪𝗢 combinations of salt and water will likely reach a higher temperature than either Brand A or Brand B?

A.Choice: 75.0 g of salt and 250 mL of water

B.Choice: 100.0 g of salt and 250 mL of water

C.Choice: 100.0 g of salt and 400 mL of water

D.Choice: 125.0 g of salt and 400 mL of water

E.Choice: 150.0 g of salt and 400 mL of water

Content: Use the information in Source 1c to help you answer this question.

The student looks at the hot packs on the bench and determines that the hot packs and the bench can be thought of as two interacting systems. The student wants to model energy flow and average kinetic energy of the particles at different locations as these two systems interact.
Follow these steps to complete the student's model.

𝗦𝗧𝗘𝗣 𝟭: Look at these six particle pictures, labeled A–F. Each picture represents the motion of the particles at one location in the model.

𝗦𝗧𝗘𝗣 𝟮: Write the letter of the picture (A–F) that 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 represents the motion of the particles in each white box on the model. Each letter should only be used one time.

𝗦𝗧𝗘𝗣 𝟯: On the right side of the model, write the letter of the arrow (G or H) that shows the direction in which energy is transferred between the hot pack and the cold bench in this system.
Use the information in Source 1d to help you answer this question.

Explain how the student should redesign the procedure to test how the ratio between the mass of a hot pack and the mass of a water sample relates to temperature change. Use information about proportion and quantity to support your explanation.
